awd_titl_txt: Biomechanical Mechanisms of Oncogenic Epithelial to Mesenchymal Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
1134201
Ghadiali

Cancer is a major cause of death in the United States. Although uncontrolled cell division is a hallmark of tumor formation, the spread of cancer cells from a primary tumor to other organs, i.e. metastasis, is the key feature that leads to high mortality rates. During metastasis, epithelial cancer cells detach from the primary tumor site and acquire a highly motile and/or mesenchymal phenotype. Migration/invasion of these cells into surrounding tissue and the circulatory/lymphatic system leads to colonization of distal tissues and secondary tumor formation. The central biological mechanism responsible for metastasis is known as epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT). In addition to its role in cancer metastasis, EMT is a fundamental biological process that plays an important role in embryonic development, wound healing and organ fibrosis. During EMT polarized epithelial cells undergo dramatic biochemical and biostructural changes and acquire a mesenchymal phenotype with enhanced migratory and invasive capacity. Although many of the biochemical signaling events that occur during oncogenic EMT are known, the biomechanical mechanisms governing oncogenic EMT are not well established. Furthermore, although it is well established that the tumor microenvironment can influence cancer progression and that increased tumor stiffness is a diagnostic indicator of advanced disease, there is limited information about how changes in the tumor?s biomechanical properties (i.e. matrix stiffness) influence EMT and metastatic potential.

This proposal utilizes a combination of biophysical, molecular biology and quantitative engineering tools to investigate the biomechanical mechanisms governing oncogenic EMT and to investigate how changes tissue/matrix mechanics influences EMT and metastasis. Sophisticated experimental techniques will be used to characterize changes in cellular mechanics during EMT in different cancer cells. Several biomechanical markers of EMT (i.e. stiffness, viscoelasticity and contractility) will be correlated with cell migration and invasion behaviors. In addition to establishing a unique set of biomechanical markers of EMT, these studies will also provide an innovative way to quantitatively assess metastatic potential based on the cell's mechanical phenotype. Experimental techniques will also be used to investigate how changes in substrate/matrix stiffness influence the biomechanical and biochemical signaling mechanisms responsible for oncogenic EMT. Finally, three-dimensional multi-scale computational models of tumor cell detachment and migration/invasion will be developed and these computational models will be used to develop new insights into how changes in cell mechanics may be used to mitigate metastasis. The proposed research studies will provide training for a post-doctoral research scientist and undergraduate/graduate students in biomedical engineering at The Ohio State University and will also be integrated into an undergraduate course in quantitative physiology. Outreach activities included contributing to a summer educational program for high school students in computational modeling hosted by the Ohio Supercomputer Center.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Cancer is a major cause of death in the United States and the spread of cancer cells from the primary tumor to other organs, i.e. metastasis, is the key feature responsible for high mortality rates. During metastasis, cancer cells can undergo a biological process known as epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) which allows the cells to become highly mobile and invasive. Although investigators have previously investigated the biochemical signaling events that regulate EMT, the goal of this NSF project was to investigate both how EMT alters the cancer cell’s biophysical properties and if targeting these biophysical properties maybe an effective way to reverse EMT and reduce metastatic potential. We have also use sophisticated computational modeling techniques to determine what types of changes in cellular biomechanics might be most effective at altering cancer cell migration.

Intellectual Merit: Although several investigators have demonstrated that cancer cells alter their biophysical and biomechanical properties, prior to this project, there was conflicting information regarding what types of changes in cellular biophysics would facilitate metastasis. First, several research groups have reported that cancer cells in the circulation (blood or lymphatics) are “softer” than other cells and have attempted to use this information to isolate circulating cancer cells for diagnostic purposes. However, other research groups (including ours) have demonstrated that during EMT biostructural changes at the molecular level (actin reorganization), results in a “stiffer” cell that also generates more contractile force. Therefore, prior to this project, there was conflicting information about if :"softer" or "stiffer" cancer cells are more invasive and/or metastatic. Using a combination of experimental and computational tools, this project has provided important new information to this field that clarifies the dynamic changes in cancer cell mechanics which facilitate increased single cell invasion. Specifically, experiments in our lab indicate that during EMT, cancer cells within a cluster (representing the initial tumor) become “stiffer” and computational models indicate that this increase in cell stiffness allows the cells to transmit contractile forces to cell-cell adhesions. This enhanced force transmission leads to the rupture of cell-cell adhesions and the detachment of individual cells from the initial tumor. Interestingly, after detachment from the initial tumor, the individual cells become significantly “softer” and experimental and computational studies indicate that this decrease in cell stiffness allows the cells to squeeze through pores in the surrounding tissue. Therefore, our work has demonstrated that dynamic changes in cell mechanics during EMT greatly facilitate the detachment and invasion of cancer cells that leads to metastasis.

In addition to identifying the basic biophysical mechanisms of cancer cell detachment and invasion during EMT, our results also suggested that even though cancer cells in the circulation may be “softer”, decreasing the stiffness of cancer cells within the primary tumor may prevent the initial detachment required for invasion. In this project, we have used a combination of in-vitro cell culture and in-vivo animal experiments to test this hypothesis. First, molecular biology tools were used to reduce the expression of a protein involved in plasma membrane repair (Myoferlin) in highly invasive, triple negative breast cancer cells. In addition to upregulating epithelial gene markers, this “silencing” of Myoferlin also resulted in decreased cell stiffness and contractility indicating a biophysical reversal of EMT. Live-cell imaging studies indicated that although the triple negative breast cancer cells quickly detach from the initial cluster and rap...

Cancer is a major cause of death in the United States and the spread of cancer cells from the primary tumor to other organs, i.e. metastasis, is the key feature responsible for high mortality rates. During metastasis, cancer cells can undergo a biological process known as epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) which allows the cells to become highly mobile and invasive. Although investigators have previously investigated the biochemical signaling events that regulate EMT, the goal of this NSF project was to investigate both how EMT alters the cancer cellÆs biophysical properties and if targeting these biophysical properties maybe an effective way to reverse EMT and reduce metastatic potential. We have also use sophisticated computational modeling techniques to determine what types of changes in cellular biomechanics might be most effective at altering cancer cell migration.

Intellectual Merit: Although several investigators have demonstrated that cancer cells alter their biophysical and biomechanical properties, prior to this project, there was conflicting information regarding what types of changes in cellular biophysics would facilitate metastasis. First, several research groups have reported that cancer cells in the circulation (blood or lymphatics) are "softer" than other cells and have attempted to use this information to isolate circulating cancer cells for diagnostic purposes. However, other research groups (including ours) have demonstrated that during EMT biostructural changes at the molecular level (actin reorganization), results in a "stiffer" cell that also generates more contractile force. Therefore, prior to this project, there was conflicting information about if :"softer" or "stiffer" cancer cells are more invasive and/or metastatic. Using a combination of experimental and computational tools, this project has provided important new information to this field that clarifies the dynamic changes in cancer cell mechanics which facilitate increased single cell invasion. Specifically, experiments in our lab indicate that during EMT, cancer cells within a cluster (representing the initial tumor) become "stiffer" and computational models indicate that this increase in cell stiffness allows the cells to transmit contractile forces to cell-cell adhesions. This enhanced force transmission leads to the rupture of cell-cell adhesions and the detachment of individual cells from the initial tumor. Interestingly, after detachment from the initial tumor, the individual cells become significantly "softer" and experimental and computational studies indicate that this decrease in cell stiffness allows the cells to squeeze through pores in the surrounding tissue. Therefore, our work has demonstrated that dynamic changes in cell mechanics during EMT greatly facilitate the detachment and invasion of cancer cells that leads to metastasis.

In addition to identifying the basic biophysical mechanisms of cancer cell detachment and invasion during EMT, our results also suggested that even though cancer cells in the circulation may be "softer", decreasing the stiffness of cancer cells within the primary tumor may prevent the initial detachment required for invasion. In this project, we have used a combination of in-vitro cell culture and in-vivo animal experiments to test this hypothesis. First, molecular biology tools were used to reduce the expression of a protein involved in plasma membrane repair (Myoferlin) in highly invasive, triple negative breast cancer cells. In addition to upregulating epithelial gene markers, this "silencing" of Myoferlin also resulted in decreased cell stiffness and contractility indicating a biophysical reversal of EMT. Live-cell imaging studies indicated that although the triple negative breast cancer cells quickly detach from the initial cluster and rapidly invade into simulated tissue, silencing Myoferlin resulted in dramatically less detachment and a much slower migration velocity.
